On Tue, 15 Jun 2004, Sadhasivam Jayabalaganesan wrote:

> We have a requirement to clone certain set of database table records and
> move to mirror tables in other schema. This is a legacy application and
> was done in Oracle PL/SQL. How do I write unit test cases to make sure
> the selected records are moved correctly?

Having done quite a lot of this sort of thing, I'd do what I've done
before: forget about JUnit and unit tests, and write a functional test
for the mover. Typically, my test would either restore a database dump
or load up test data into a test schema "old", load up the new schema
into a test schema called "new", run the conversion program, and then
select stuff out of "new" and make sure that it appears correct.

> Further we have another requirement. we have a modeling engine related
> to supply-chain. The engine captures the model and validate it and write
> its metric data to some standard tables..( only output to the table).
>
> So how do I write JUNIT test cases to validate the engine process ?

Well, this is pretty vague, so I'll give you the vague answer:

    Send known input to your routine, and verify that the output is the
    expected output.

Again, JUnit is just--sometimes--a natural consequence of deciding to
test something. You don't start out saying, "let's use JUnit." You start
out saying, "let's test this," and sometimes JUnit is the handiest tool.

cjs
